sn35.90:1.2.eng: That’s why the Realized One lives unperturbed, with dart drawn out.

sn35.90:1.3.eng: Now, a mendicant might wish: ‘May I live unperturbed, with dart drawn out.’
sn35.90:1.3.comm: The fourth absorption is called “imperturbable” due to its freedom from the reactivity of pleasure and pain.This discourse, however, deals with the ultimate imperturbability of the perfected one.

sn35.90:1.8.pli: Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi na maññeyya, tasmimpi na maññeyya, tatopi na maññeyya, taṃ meti na maññeyya.
sn35.90:1.8.eng: Let them not conceive anything to be the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact. Let them not conceive it in that, let them not conceive it as that, and let them not conceive that ‘that is mine.’

sn35.90:3.6.eng: Let them not conceive anything to be the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact. Let them not conceive it in that, let them not conceive it as that, and let them not conceive that ‘that is mine.’

sn35.90:3.7.eng: Let them not conceive anything to be all, let them not conceive it in all, let them not conceive it as all, let them not conceive that ‘all is mine’.

sn35.90:4.1.pli: So evaṃ amaññamāno na kiñcipi loke upādiyati.
sn35.90:4.1.eng: Not conceiving, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.

sn35.90:4.2.pli: Anupādiyaṃ na paritassati. Aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati.
sn35.90:4.2.eng: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

sn35.90:4.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.90:4.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.92:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you a duality.
sn35.92:1.1.comm: In this discourse and the next, the Buddha discusses the structure of sense activity as the duality of interior and exterior. From the sparse hints in the discourses themselves, it seems he is critiquing the doctrine of infinite, non-dual consciousness taught by Yājñavalkya especially in Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4 = 4.5 and 4.3.23–32.

sn35.92:1.4.pli: Cakkhuñceva rūpā ca, sotañceva saddā ca, ghānañceva gandhā ca, jivhā ceva rasā ca, kāyo ceva phoṭṭhabbā ca, mano ceva dhammā ca—
sn35.92:1.4.eng: It’s just the eye and sights, the ear and sounds, the nose and smells, the tongue and tastes, the body and touches, and the mind and ideas.

sn35.92:2.1.eng: Mendicants, suppose someone was to say:

sn35.92:2.2.pli: ‘ahametaṃ dvayaṃ paccakkhāya aññaṃ dvayaṃ paññapessāmī’ti, tassa vācāvatthukamevassa.
sn35.92:2.2.eng: ‘I’ll deny this duality and describe another duality.’ They’d have no grounds for that claim,
sn35.92:2.2.comm: The same “duality” is described as the (sentient) body and “external” name and form, which are essential for contact through the six senses (SN 12.19:1.3). | Compare Yājñavalkya’s culminating philosophy: “For when there is a duality, as it were, then one sees the other; one smells, tastes, hears, greets, thinks of, touches, and cognizes the other. But when this All has become the Self, how and what would one see? How and what would one smell, taste, greet, hear, think, touch, or cognize? By what would one cognize that which cognizes this All? This Self is not that, not that! … By what would one cognize the cognizer?” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.14 = 4.5.15; readings vary). According to the Buddha, the dualistic structure of experience is primary; the mind functions as a duality. If one asserts, with Yājñavalkya, that “there is no second reality here that he could see as something distinct and separate from himself” (BU 4.3.23), how can one then assert that the primordial person split in two to make man and woman (BU 1.4.3); or that there is a duality of truth and falsehood (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.1.1.4)? Yājñavalkya denies the duality of self and other implicit in the structure of the senses, yet asserts the dualities of truth and falsehood, mortality and immortality, and man and woman. The implication is that such an assertion is incoherent, for to make such an assertion relies on the duality of speech and the senses. For all his “nondual” talk, Yājñavalkya ends up asserting one axis of duality, namely the eternal survival of the soul (as at SN 12.15:2.1) against the transience of worldly things. While there is no necessary correspondence between the dualities of interior/exterior and eternalism/annihilationism, those who focus on the inner consciousness, which appears to the unwary as ever-present, tend to fall into eternalism, while those who focus on the ephemeral material world of the exterior senses tend to be annihilationists. Epistemology shapes metaphysics.

sn35.93:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, consciousness originates dependent on a duality.
sn35.93:1.1.comm: Yājñavalkya taught that the ultimate Self was “this great reality, infinite, unbounded, a sheer mass of consciousness” (idaṁ mahadbhūtam anantam apāraṁ vijñānaghana eva, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12). It arises as an individuated self from the mass of particularized elements making up the world, but for the realized being it returns to its essential oneness with Divinity. Thus Yājñavalkya spoke of the “uncognized cognizer”, the eternal and changeless core of awareness at the heart of the ephemeral world of changing illusions. Rejecting this, the Buddha asserts that consciousness, far from being an eternal or mysterious essence, is dependent on the dualistic structure of experience.

sn35.93:1.3.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ.

sn35.94:2.5.eng: The field of mind contact brings happiness when it’s well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.

sn35.94:2.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cha phassāyatanā sudantā suguttā surakkhitā susaṃvutā sukhādhivāhā hontī”ti.
sn35.94:2.6.eng: These six fields of contact bring happiness when they’re well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.”

sn35.94:2.7.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn35.94:2.8.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn35.94:3.1.eng: “Mendicants, it’s just the six fields of contact

sn35.94:3.2.eng: that lead the unrestrained to suffering.

sn35.94:3.3.eng: Those who understand how to restrain them

sn35.94:3.4.eng: live with faith as partner, not festering.

sn35.94:4.1.comm: This series of verses resembles those attributed to Vardhamāna (Mahāvīra) at Isibhāsiyāiṁ 29. The same series of verses also contains parallels to Snp 5.2:3.1, SN 1.6:3.1, and DN 2:29.4 = MN 56:12.2.

sn35.94:4.3.eng: get rid of all manner of desire for the pleasant,

sn35.94:4.4.eng: without hating what you don’t like.

sn35.94:5.1.eng: When you’ve heard sounds both liked and disliked,

sn35.94:5.2.eng: don’t fall under the thrall of sounds you like,

sn35.94:5.3.eng: get rid of hate for the unliked,

sn35.94:5.4.eng: and don’t hurt your mind <j>by thinking of what you don’t like.

sn35.94:6.1.eng: When you’ve smelled a pleasant, fragrant scent,

sn35.94:6.2.eng: and one that’s foul and unpleasant,

sn35.94:6.3.eng: get rid of repulsion for the unpleasant,

sn35.94:6.4.eng: while not yielding to desire for the pleasant.

sn35.94:7.1.eng: When you’ve enjoyed a sweet, delicious taste,

sn35.94:7.2.eng: and sometimes those that are bitter,

sn35.94:7.3.eng: don’t be attached to enjoying sweet tastes,

sn35.94:8.1.eng: Don’t be intoxicated by a pleasant touch,

sn35.94:8.2.eng: and don’t tremble at a painful touch.

sn35.94:8.3.eng: Look with equanimity at the duality <j>of pleasant and painful contacts,
sn35.94:8.3.comm: The mention of “duality” links this to the preceding two discourses.

sn35.94:9.1.eng: People generally let their perceptions proliferate;

sn35.94:9.2.eng: perceiving and proliferating, they are attracted.
sn35.94:9.2.comm: “Attraction” (upāya, verb form upeti, here spelled upayanti) is the initial stage in the process of becoming attached (eg. SN 12.15:2.5).

sn35.94:9.3.eng: Casting aside all mental constructions of the domestic life,
sn35.94:9.3.comm: This unusual use of manomayaṁ (normally “mind-made”, here “mental construction”) parallels vitakkaṁ at Thag 21.1:6.2.

sn35.94:10.1.eng: When the mind is well developed like this <j>regarding the six,

sn35.94:10.2.eng: it doesn’t waver at contacts at all.

sn35.94:10.3.eng: Mendicants, those who have mastered greed and hate
